France faces prospect of paying higher borrowing costs than Italy
subhead: Rome has significantly reduced its public deficit over the past three years, while Paris has allowed its own to spiral. In the eyes of investors, Italy is now as credible as France, despite a heavier debt burden. On the markets, the gap in interest rates between the two countries has nearly vanished.
byline: By Denis Cosnard and Allan Kaval (Rome (Italy) correspondent)

title: 'By choosing AI for its remembrance policy, the French government is automating an intellectual process'
subhead: Historian Frédéric Clavert writes that the use of artificial intelligence (AI) by French ministries to create commemorative videos can result in highly questionable outcomes.

title: With 'Weapons,' Zach Cregger films the nightmare lurking beneath ordinary America
subhead: In this horror fable, the mysterious disappearance of some 20 children mirrors the flaws that consume the adults.

title: 'Like Joan of Arc': Marthe Robin, the recluse who sought to 'raise France up again'
subhead: 'Marthe Robin, Saint or Fraud?' (2/5). In the 1930s, the Catholic mystic, whose words became increasingly political, started developing the Foyers de Charité, a spiritual and educational organization aimed at fostering France's spiritual renewal.

title: Tel Aviv's large protests are not enough to worry Netanyahu
subhead: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered on Sunday evening in solidarity with the hostages held in Gaza and to demand an end to the war in the Palestinian enclave. The Israeli prime minister's camp accused the protesters of playing into Hamas's hands.
byline: By Luc Bronner (Tel Aviv, special correspondent)

title: A winemaker, his daughter and a vintage for their undocumented workers
subhead: In southeastern France, Philippe Grisard and his daughter, Nadège, rely daily on undocumented workers to help tend their vineyard. To draw attention to their workers' precarious legal status, they named one of their vintages 'Sans eux' ('Without Them').
